author: P Sudakar
text:
The first reactor of Kudankulam Nuclear Power Project on Monday resumed generating electricity. Earlier, it had been stopped for mandatory tests as the turbine was synchronised with the southern grid.

Speaking to The Hindu, Site Director, KKNPP, R.S. Sundar said the turbine, which was operated at 11.16 p.m. on Sunday generated around 300 MWe at 8 a.m. and it went up to 500 MWe at 5 p.m.

“We are increasing the quantum of power generation gradually even as we are closely monitoring every parameter of the reactor and the turbine,” Mr. Sundar said, adding that the reactor might reach its maximum capacity of 1,000 MWe in the next 72 hours. He expressed satisfaction over the performance of the reactor and the turbine after the annual fuel outage and the subsequent maintenance carried out over a period of seven months.

Second unit

On the progress made in commissioning the second unit of KKNPP, he said loading of enriched uranium fuel would commence either in the last week of February or first week of March after getting the Atomic Energy Regulatory Board’s nod.
title: Production from Kudankulam reactor crosses 500 MWe
